name: Vietnamese Steamed Rice Noodle Sheets/Rolls (Bánh Ướt)
description: Soft, delicate, and full of flavor, bánh ướt is a Vietnamese street food that you won't want to miss. These thin rice sheets are steamed to perfection and then served with various toppings, such as cucumbers, Vietnamese ham, beansprouts, and a flavorful dipping sauce. This recipe makes 15 rolls/rice sheets.
keywords: Bánh Ướt, banh uot recipe, Vietnamese steamed rice rolls without fillings, Vietnamese steamed rice rolls without stuffing, Vietnamese steamed rice rolls without pork, Vietnamese rice rolls, Vietnamese steamed rice rolls, how to make Vietnamese rice rolls, how to make Vietnamese steamed rice rolls, Vietnamese rice sheets, how to make Vietnamese steamed rice sheets, banh uot, Vietnamese steamed rice rolls, Vietnamese steamed rice cakes, wet rice noodle rolls, Vietnamese wet cake, plain rice rolls, how to make rice rolls with no stuffing, how to make rice rolls without filling, Vietnamese plain steamed rice rolls, Vietnamese famous food, Vietnamese street food, Vietnamese rice rolls, Vietnamese steamed rice sheets, banh uot with pan, how to steam banh uot at home, how to steam banh uot without steamer, rice flour, regular rice flour, tapioca starch, potato starch, mung bean starch, water, salt, steaming rice roll hack, Vietnamese banh uot, Vietnamese steamed rice rolls recipe, Vietnamese steamed rice sheet recipe, how to make banh uot, how to steam banh uot, banh cuon vs banh uot

video.name: Vietnamese Steamed Rice Noodle Sheets/Rolls (Bánh Ướt)
video.description: Soft, delicate, and full of flavor, bánh ướt is a Vietnamese street food that you won't want to miss. These thin rice sheets are steamed to perfection and then served with various toppings, such as cucumbers, Vietnamese ham, beansprouts, and a flavorful dipping sauce. This recipe makes 15 rolls/rice sheets. Full recipe on https://www.vickypham.com/blog/ban-uot

recipeIngredient: ½ cup potato starch (or same amount of tapioca starch)
Optional herbs (Thai basil, mint, and Vietnamese coriander rau ram)
Vietnamese sweet chili dipping sauce (Nuoc Cham)
recipeInstructions: Make the batter. Combine rice flour, tapioca starch, potato starch, salt and water. Mix together until flour and starches have completely dissolved. Let it sit for 30 minutes to bloom.
Prepare a tray by greasing with shallot oil. Set aside. This will be used to place the finished rice rolls.

Fill a large pot/skillet or a large steamer with about 2 inches of water. If using a large pot/skillet, place a shallow bowl or plate at the bottom of the pot to keep the baking pan from sitting directly in the water. Place the baking pan inside. I'm using a 9-inch round nonstick cake pan. Bring the water to a boil over medium-high heat.
Pour about ⅓ cup of batter onto the baking pan and swirl it to form a thin even layer. Cover the pot with a lid and steam for about 2 minutes, or until the batter is translucent and cooked through.

Carefully remove the baking pan with tongs or mittens. Use a wooden chopstick to trace the outline of the rice sheet along the edges to loosen them. The wooden chopstick prevents sticking. Use the chopstick to nudge one side of the rice sheet so you can lift it off. I find it too be much easier if you roll it off rather than trying to lift the whole sheet. If you find it too fragile, allow the rice sheet to cool for about 30 seconds to 1 minute.
Transfer the Banh Uot to the oiled tray and brush the sheet or rolls with more shallot oil to prevent sticking.
Repeat the above steps until batter runs out. Once you get the hang of it, you can get multiple trays going at once.
Assemble 4-5 rolls or sheets per person. Top with desired vegetables and serve with a small bowl of sauce on the side for pouring or dipping and enjoy.
